definition: A married woman, especially an elderly married woman, or a woman old enough to be the mother of a family, whether actually so or not; a woman possessing the gravity suitable to a mother.
A fascinating woman; a woman, especially a young woman or a girl, possessed of peculiar attractions, whether of beauty or of manners; a bewitching or charming young woman or girl.

A woman filling the place, but without the rights, of a wife; a woman having an ongoing usually exclusive sexual relationship with a man, who may provide her with financial support in return; a concubine; a loose woman with whom one consorts habitually.
A woman who prostitutes herself for hire; a prostitute; a harlot.
Slang   A woman regarded as tawdry or sexually promiscuous.
An unmarried woman; usually, a young unmarried woman; esp., a girl; a virgin; a maiden.
An unmarried woman; a girl or woman who has not experienced sexual intercourse; a virgin; a maid.
A woman versed in magical arts; a sorceress; also, a woman who fascinates.
A woman of good family or of good breeding; a woman above the vulgar.
Ecclesiastical   Used as a form of address for such a woman, alone or followed by the woman's name.
a woman possessing heroic qualities or a woman who has performed heroic deeds
A warlike or masculine woman; hence, a quarrelsome woman; a virago.
An old woman; -- usually in contempt.
A young woman; a girl; a sweetheart.
A grandmother; a grandam; familiarly, an old woman.
A fair lady; a handsome woman of society; a recognized or reigning beauty.
An elderly woman of high social station.

An unmarried woman (so called because she was supposed to occupy herself with spinning): the legal designation in England of all unmarried women from a viscount's daughter downward; popularly, an elderly unmarried woman; an “old maid”: sometimes used adjectively.
A venerated old woman.
A woman employed to take care of children.
An alluring, bewitching woman. See Usage Note at -ess.
A woman who acts out the role of the dominating partner in a sadomasochistic relationship.
A woman who nourishes or suckles an infant; specifically, a woman who suckles the infant of another: commonly called a wet-nurse; also, a female servant who has the core of a child or of children.
a girl or young woman who is unmarried
A woman who makes teasing sexual or romantic overtures; a flirt.

A woman in general; particularly, a woman of mature years, a married woman, or the mistress of a household: formerly often used (like the modern Mrs.) as a title, before either the surname or the Christian name.
a woman who is considered to be dangerously seductive
A woman's petticoat; the part of a woman's dress that hangs from the waist; formerly, a woman's lap.
a woman who embroiders; a woman embroiderer.
A woman who is affectedly fastidious in language or taste; a woman who is over-refined: from the title of Molière's “Les précieuses ridicules.”
A woman who makes a will or testament; a woman who has made a will or testament and dies leaving it in force.
A woman who is slovenly in dress, appearance, or habits; a slattern; a draggletail; also, a woman morally loose.
A woman who spins flax; hence, a common woman.
An odious old woman; a hag; a vixenish woman.
A woman predictor; a woman soothsayer.
A person, usually a woman, who is trained to assist women in childbirth. Also called regionally granny, granny woman.
A woman; a young or unmarried woman; a girl.
A woman who rules over an empire; a woman invested with imperial power or sovereignty.
A young woman who works.
A woman held unwillingly for purposes of prostitution.
A cross, old-fashioned person; esp., an old woman; a gossip.
A woman who cohabits with a man without being his wife; a paramour.
Slang   A sexually promiscuous woman.
An untidy, dirty woman.
an ugly or crude person, especially an ugly woman.
A fierce, violent person, esp. a woman.
a malicious woman with a fierce temper
A woman regarded as cruel or malicious.
A woman prostitute hired by telephone.
A woman forced to serve as a prostitute for Japanese servicemen during World War II.
A woman belonging to the demimonde.
a woman who cohabits with an important man
Slang   A woman considered ugly or unkempt.
a malicious woman with a fierce temper
a woman forced into prostitution for Japanese servicemen during World War II
A shrewish woman.
A woman who prostitutes her body for hire; a prostitute; a common woman; a strumpet.
An old woman in general; especially, an ugly old woman; a hag.
A woman appearing for the first time before the public or in society; specifically, an actress or a singer making her first appearance in public, or a young woman during her first season in society.
an adulterous woman; a woman who has an ongoing extramarital sexual relationship with a man
an adulterous woman; a woman who has an ongoing extramarital sexual relationship with a man
A woman of extraordinary stature, strength, and courage; a woman who has the robust body and masculine mind of a man; a female warrior.
A woman who has a jointure.
A woman.
A woman exercising the functions of an executor.
A woman who farms.
Used as a symbol of the holder of a distaff; hence, a woman; women, collectively.
A woman who divines.
A woman who imposes upon or deceives others.
A young unmarried woman; a girl; a maiden.
A woman who dictates or commands.
A woman who hunts or follows the chase.
A woman who comforts.
A woman invested with authority to command.
A woman who knits.
A woman hired for odd work or for single days.
A woman of superior charms or excellence.
A female governor; a woman invested with authority to control and direct; especially, one intrusted with the care and instruction of children, -- usually in their homes.
A foolish or thoughtless young woman.
A woman who has taken a vow; a nun.
A woman who wails or mourns: used in the quotation with reference to professional mourners.
A woman who waits at table: originally used only of one who served in a place of public entertainment.
A woman who manages a boat.
A woman of extraordinary size.
A woman who deals in articles of fashion, particularly in women's apparel; a milliner or dressmaker.
A woman who renders professional aid to women in labor; a midwife.
The consort of a peer; a woman ennobled by descent, by creation, or by marriage.
A woman who is a poet.
A woman who officiates in sacred rites.
A female prior, having charge of a religious house; a woman who is the coadjutor of and next in rank to an abbess.
A quarrelsome woman; a common scold.
A woman whose occupation is sewing
A female seducer; a woman who leads a man astray.
A woman who sews; a seamstress.
A woman who shoots; a female archer.
A female steward; specifically, a woman who waits upon women in passenger-vessels, etc.
Archaic   Used formerly as a courtesy title before the surname of a married woman not of noble birth.
An old woman; and old gossip.
A woman aviator (in senses 1 or 3).
A woman who sells butter.
A woman who chides; a scold.
A nun; a woman who has vowed religious retirement. Also written cloisteress.
A woman who creates, produces, or constitutes.
A female detractor; a censorious woman.
A woman who nourishes or rears; a nurse.
A female heir; especially, a woman inheriting or who is expected to inherit considerable wealth.
A woman given to intrigue; a female intriguer.
A female gossip; a talkative woman.
A woman who cleaned wool.
A female knight; a woman of knightly character, or who is the wife of a knight.
A young woman.
A woman who supports, protects, or champions someone or something, such as an institution, event, or cause; a sponsor or benefactor.
A woman doorkeeper or porter, especially in a convent.
A woman who sculptures. See Usage Note at -ess.
A woman who performs songs, especially ballads or popular songs.
A woman who practices sorcery.
A female stageplayer; a woman who acts a part.
A city woman.
the state of being an adult woman
A woman graduate or former student of a school, college, or university. See Usage Note at alumnus.
A woman who has retired into seclusion for religious reasons.
A woman whose sexual orientation is to women.
A woman holding the title to a barony.
A woman sovereign.
a woman shepherd
A woman who belongs to a religious order or congregation devoted to active service or meditation, living under vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience.
a woman who is a mediator
the state of being an adult woman
A woman who sins; a female sinner.
a woman author
A woman who operates an aircraft; a woman pilot.
A woman guilty of fornication.
A woman who ministers.
A woman who persecutes.
A woman who solicits.
A woman who performs the duties of a tutor; an instructress.
A woman who is a votary.
A bride or wife; a married woman.
One who flirts; esp., a woman who acts with giddiness, or plays at courtship; a coquette; a pert girl.
A woman who capriciously deceives her lover; a coquette; a flirt.
A woman who is mayor.
an unusually attractive person, especially a beautiful woman.

A gentlewoman; -- an appellation or courteous form of address given to a lady, especially an elderly or a married lady; -- much used in the address, at the beginning of a letter, to a woman. The corresponding word in addressing a man is <contr>Sir</contr>; often abbreviated ma'am when used as a term of address.
A person who is physically very attractive, especially a beautiful woman.
The wife or the widow of a marquis; a woman who has the rank and dignity of a marquis.
an attractive woman or girl.
A woman in love; a mistress.
a young woman who is thought to have sex appeal
A lewd woman; a harlot.
a strikingly beautiful woman.
An ugly old woman.
a young woman; -- often considered offensive.
A worthless woman; a strumpet.
a woman employed by a bar to act as a companion to men customers.
An Italian title of respect for a young woman, equivalent to Miss in English, Mademoiselle in French, etc.
Informal   An unmarried woman.
A woman prostitute.
A bluestocking; a literary woman.
A person who keeps a house of prostitution, or procures women for a lewd purpose; a procurer or procuress; a lewd person; -- usually applied to a woman.
A maiden; a girl; a young woman.
A young girl or an unmarried woman who attends on a bride at her marriage during the ceremony.
A bold, vicious woman; a termagant.
A person who has been divorced. The term is more commonly applied to a woman.
A frantic or frenzied woman.
A woman who is the head of a household or the mother of a family.

A woman who is the governor of a country, province, or colony, ruling as the representative of a sovereign.

A member of the “Blue-stocking Club,” especially a woman (see above); by extension, any woman with a taste for learning or literature; a literary woman: originally used in derision or contempt, and implying a neglect on the part of such women of their domestic duties or a departure from their “proper sphere”; now hardly used except historically or humorously.
A young woman, especially one in the 1920s who showed disdain for conventional dress and behavior.
A young woman regarded as flirtatious or frivolous.
A slim, graceful woman or girl.
A woman who manages her own household as her main occupation.
Offensive   A woman who has remained single beyond the conventional age for marrying.
A woman of mixed racial ancestry, especially of mixed European and Native American ancestry.
Offensive   Used as a disparaging term for a non-Jewish girl or woman.
Informal   A woman considered to have sex appeal.
Informal   Used as a familiar term of address for a young woman or girl.
A girl or young woman who is considered pert, flirtatious, or impudent.
Used as a courtesy title for a married woman in an Italian-speaking area, equivalent to Mrs.
A beautiful person, esp. a beautiful woman.

(Yiddish) an attractive, unconventional woman

A female housekeeper; a woman who manages domestic affairs; a thirfty woman.
A woman born, or dwelling, in the country, as opposed to the city; a woman born or dwelling in the same country with another native or inhabitant.
In German use, a woman; a married woman; a wife; lady; as a title, Madame; Mrs.: as, Frau Schultze.
A woman, particularly an Indian woman.

A woman employed to dress, or to attend to the dressing or dresses of, others; a lady's-maid; a female dresser in a theater; a tiring-woman.
A woman who betrays her trust; a perfidious woman; a female traitor: often used in a weakened, half-playful sense.
Plural of woman.
A woman who picks up rags in the streets; hence, a low, vulgar woman.
A woman who is an expert in sewing or embroidery, or one whose business is sewing or embroidery; specifically, a woman who earns a living by sewing; a seamstress.
Same as oyster-woman.
A woman who sold starch for the stiffening of the great ruffs worn in the sixteenth century. The starch-woman was a favorite go-between in intrigues. See the quotation.
A woman who bears a child for another person, often for pay, either through artificial insemination or by carrying until birth another woman's surgically implanted fertilized egg.
A woman; especially, a Dutch or German woman.

A woman's family name before she is married. Used of a surname that is replaced by a woman when she marries. Also called birth name.
A position for sexual intercourse in which a woman and man lie facing each other, with the woman on the bottom and the man on the top.

A woman who is devoted to literary or scholarly pursuits: "[Eva Le Gallienne] was ... a woman of letters who produced forcefully elegant translations of Ibsen and Hans Christian Andersen”  ( Margo Jefferson).

A peculiar domestic relation maintained between the sexes in certain quasi-religious and communistic communities in the United States, especially (formerly) among the Perfectionists of the Oneida Community, by which every man was virtually the husband of every woman, and every woman the wife of every man.

A female genoblast (which see): opposed to arsenoblast.
A tirewoman; a female dresser, as in a theater.
A female Titan; a woman of surpassing size or power.
A female actor of tragedy; a tragic actress.
A female traitor; a traitress.
A woman who has charge of a treasure; a female treasurer.
A female Turk. Disdainful Turkess.
A female guardian.
In archaeology, an ancient Etruscan female head-dress of conical form; hence, any similar head-dress.
A woman who is an umpire; a female umpire.
A female who unfolds or discloses.
A female usurper.
A female varlet; a waiting-woman. Richardson, Clarissa Harlowe, I. xxxi.
A female avenger.
A female vicar; the wife of a vicar.
A female visitor. Charlotte Brontë, Shirley, xxxiii.
A woman who makes or sells wafers; a female waferer.
A female warrior.
A female weaver.
The leading female character in the merrymakings at Whitsuntide.
A female author, designer, producer, or performer of any work.
An American singing bird (Dolichonyx oryzivorus). The male is black and white; the female is brown; -- called also, ricebird, reedbird, and Boblincoln.
a female breast.
a female businessman.
A female juggler.
The state of being a maid or maiden; the state of an unmarried female; virginity.
A female mandarin.
An adherent of Marcellina, a female Gnostic of the second century, and a teacher of Gnosticism in Rome. Also Marcellinian.
A female under age.
A female Moabite.
A female umpire or judge.
A female mulatto.
A female who commits murder.
A female teacher of music.
A female nail-maker.
A female neatherd; a neatress.
A female neatherd.
A female negotiator.
A female neighbor.
A female nomenclator.
A female offender.
A female ogre.
In botany, one of those sporanges of Lycopodiaceæ which contain the larger or female spores.
A female pander; a procuress.
A female native of or resident in Paris.
A female pauper.
A woman who writes with a pen; a female writer; an authoress.
A female perturber; a woman who perturbs or disturbs.
A female incendiary. See pétroleur.
A female philosopher. Carlyle, Diderot.
A female philosopher.
A female parturient for the second or some subsequent time, or one who has borne two or more children.
A female porter or keeper of a gate.
A female preceptor or teacher.
A female prelate.
A female president.
A female pimp; a bawd.
A female who produces.
A female progenitor or parent; an ancestress.
The female of the prongbuck.
A female proprietor.
A female prosecutor.
A female Quaker.
A female regent; a protectress of a kingdom.
A woman who sells at retail; a female huckster.
A female regulator; a directrix.
In law, a female relator or petitioner.
A female satrap.
A female teacher of a school; a schoolmistress.
A female deity of the ocean; a marine goddess.
A female searcher; an inventress.
A female servant, or maid-servant.
A female sexton.
A female sheriff.
A female sophist.
A woman who makes or mends shoes; a female cobbler.
A female fortune-teller.
The goosander or merganser, especially the female.
A female spectator or looker-on.
A female helper.
A female demon fabled to have sexual connection with men in their sleep.
A female who suggests.
A female supporter.
Sexual selection on the part of both male and female. Compare gyneclexis and andreclexis.
In zoology, an interval between periods in ‘heat’ when the female mammal has no sexual desire.
A female ballet-dancer.
A female singer of comic music. See buffo and bouffe.
A younger daughter or sister; a female cadet. See cadet, 2.
A subspecies (Icterus galbula galbula) of the northern oriole in its eastern range, of which the male is bright orange and black and the female olive brown with white wing bars.
The passive, female cosmic principle in Chinese dualistic philosophy.
Any of various sawflies of the family Siricidae, the female of which has a long stout ovipositor.
An external pouch or fold on the abdomen of most female marsupials, containing the mammary glands and in which the young continue to develop after leaving the uterus.
A female vampire.
A female ancestor.
a woman television reporter who coordinates a broadcast to which several correspondents contribute. Female correlate of anchorman.
A female architect.
The principal female divinity of the Phœnicians, as Baal was the principal male divinity.
a female member of a legislative body called an assembly.
A female sovereign who is independent and absolute; -- a title given to the empresses of Russia.
In antiquity, a priestess of Bacchus, or a woman who joined in the celebration of the festivals of Bacchus; a woman inspired with the bacchic frenzy. See mænad.
A female baker.
A female ballet dancer.
A baker; originally, a female baker.
A female dancer in the East Indies.
A female albino.
The production in parthenogenesis of both male and female forms.
A female apostle.
A female arbiter; an arbitratrix.
A female who asserts.
In ancient Greece, a female flute-player.
A female public dancer.
A female banker; a banker's wife.
A female barber; a barber's wife.
A female benefactor.
A female blasphemer.
A female slave. Also improperly written bondswoman.
A female brewer.
A woman who carries a canteen for soldiers; a vivandière.
A female centaur.
A woman who buys and sells; a female trader.
A female chief. Carver.
A female chieftain.
A female member of the church, specifically of the Anglican Church.
A female collector.
A female compounder.
A female consoler.
A coheir; one who has an equal portion of the inheritance in lands of his or her ancestor with others; in English law, a female coheir, or a coheiress. See coparcenary.
A female calf. See free-martin.
A female creditor.
A female fortune-teller. See cunning-man.
A female dromedary. Also written deloul.
A female who deserts.
A female disher.
A female dispenser.
One, especially a woman, whose occupation is the making of gowns and other articles of female attire.
A female elder.
The female of the stickleback.
A female who executes, accomplishes, or carries into effect. See executrix.
A factor who is a woman.
A female fautor or favorer; a patroness.
A female fellow. Compare fellow, 6.
An affianced or betrothed person, male (fiancé) or female (fiancée).
A female ancestor.
A female nourished or reared like an own daughter, though not such by birth.
A female founder; a woman who founds or establishes, as a charitable institution, or who endows with a fund, as a school or a hospital.
A female seller of fruit.
A female gambler.
A female general or commander.
A moth, Ocneria Hypogymna dispar of naturalists, the sexes of which differ much in appearance, the male being blackish-brown and the female grayish-white: so called in England. Also called gipsy.
A female minstrel.
A female minstrel.
A female glutton.
A female gnome. See gnome, 1.
In entomology, a variation or monstrosity in which the peculiar characters of the male and female are found in the same individual.
The pistil or collective pistils of a flower; the female portion of a flower as a whole: correlative to andrœcium. Also gynœcium, gynœceum.
A female player on the harp.
A female performer on the harp.
A young female terrapin, Malaclemmys palustris, measuring 5 or 6 inches along the lower shell. See cow terrapin, under terrapin.
A female heritor.
The mother of a family; the female head of a household, or of a family community.
A female incumbent.
An heiress; a female who inherits or is entitled to inherit. Also inheritrix.
A female initiator.
A female inquisitor; an inquisitive or curious woman.
A female institutor; a foundress.
A female interlocutor.
A female jailer.
A female ass; a jenny.
A female keeper, custodian, or warden.
A female sweetheart; a woman who is loved.
A female attendant upon a lady.
Measurement of the dimensions and capacity of the pelvis, especially of the adult female pelvis.
Informal   A female who is affected with nymphomania; a nymphomaniac.
A large nonmotile female gamete or egg cell, formed in an oogonium and ready for fertilization.
A fertilized female cell or zygote, especially one with thick chitinous walls, developed from a fertilized oosphere.
A female gamete, especially the larger of two gametes produced by an oogamous species.
A cell from which an egg or ovum develops by meiosis; a female gametocyte.
A female reproductive structure in certain thallophytes, usually a rounded cell or sac containing one or more oospheres.
The union of male and female gametes to form a zygote.
A female demon supposed to descend upon and have sexual intercourse with a man while he sleeps.
A sterile or otherwise sexually imperfect female calf born as the twin of a bull calf.
The condensed, inactive X-chromosome found in the nuclei of somatic cells of most female mammals. Also called sex chromatin.
Greek Mythology   A female sea monster who lived in a cave opposite Charybdis and devoured sailors.
The hybrid offspring of a male gibbon and a female siamang.
A female shaman or shamanistic healer, especially among Native American peoples.
Any of various insects of the subfamily Lacciferinae, especially Laccifer lacca of southern Asia, the female of which secretes lac.
The female head or chief proponent, as of a movement or doctrine:  the high priestess of modern art.
A tubular structure, usually concealed but sometimes extending outside the abdomen, with which many female insects deposit eggs.
The female line or maternal branch of a family.
The nucleus of a fertilized egg immediately after the male and female nuclei have fused.
Zoology   A mating pattern in which a female mates with more than one male in a single breeding season.
Zoology   A mating pattern in which a male mates with more than one female in a single breeding season.
The capacity to function either as a male or a female.
A female admonitor.
A female adventurer; a woman who tries to gain position by equivocal means.

Formerly the part sung by the highest male, or counter-tenor, voices; now the part sung by the lowest female, or contralto, voices, between in tenor and soprano. In instrumental music it now signifies the tenor.
a female domestic.
A female ambassador; also, the wife of an ambassador.
breeding from a male and female from the same parentage.
breeding from a male and female of different lineage.
A rag baby; a puppet made of cloth; hence, also, in fondness, a little girl, or a woman.
a girl who works in a mill.

The name given in some parts of the East, and especially in Egypt, to a girl whose occupation is to amuse company in the houses of the wealthy or to sing dirges at funerals; a singing girl, of a higher class than the ghawazee or dancing-girls of Egypt, with whom the almas are sometimes confounded. See ghawazee and ghaziyeh. Also spelled alme and almeh.
A French title of courtesy given to a girl or an unmarried lady, equivalent to the English Miss.
In Luzon, Philippine Islands, a young unmarried woman; a girl.
A girl or young woman who works or is engaged in some useful manual employment.
An Irish female domestic; a servant-girl.
A girl or woman with a somewhat brown or dark complexion.
A rustic girl; a gawky young woman; a wench.
A school-girl.
A young woman who tends a shop; a shop-girl.
A woman or girl whose welfare, training, or career is promoted by an influential person.
A French girl or young married woman of the lower class; more frequently, a young working woman who is fond of gallantry.

Partial or complete removal of the clitoris, prepuce, or labia of a girl or young woman, as practiced among certain cultures, especially in parts of Africa and western Asia. Also called clitoridectomy.
A girl or young woman employed in the mines of Cornwall, England.
A girl who performs the same duties as a cash-boy.
A girl brought up at a charity-school or on a charitable foundation.
A woman or girl who takes care of children during the day.
A child, generally a girl a year or two old, carried on the back by professional beggar-women.
A female servant whose business is to milk cows and work in the dairy.
Slang   A girl or young woman.
A Filipino woman or girl.
A Mexican-American woman or girl. See Usage Notes at Chicano, Latina1.
A girl or young woman.
An African-American woman or girl.
Australian Slang   A girl or young woman.
A girl or young woman employed in a business office to do odd jobs and errands.

An informal, exclusive system of mutual assistance and friendship through which women belonging to a particular group, such as the alumnae of a school, exchange favors and connections, as in politics or business: "Companies rely on an old-girl network whereby representatives use friends as contacts”  ( New York Times).
Used as a courtesy title in a German-speaking area before the name of an unmarried woman or girl.
Used as a courtesy title before the surname or full name of a girl or unmarried woman in a Spanish-speaking area.
A female servant employed in general work about a house.
A B-girl.
A daughter; a girl.
a man who is the lover of a girl or young woman
A girl or woman who milks cows.
A girl or woman with dark or brown hair.
a highly emotional and quick-tempered person (especially a girl or woman)
a man who is the lover of a girl or young woman
Offensive & Vulgar Slang   A woman or girl.
A girl or woman employed to escort people to their seats, as in a theater or stadium.
Offensive Slang   A Jewish-American girl or woman regarded as being pampered or overindulged.
A Latino woman or girl.
A girl or woman.
a man who is the lover of a girl or young woman
a man who is the lover of a girl or young woman
a woman whose merits were not been recognized but who then achieves sudden success and recognition
a man who is the lover of a girl or young woman
A word of endearment for a girl or woman.
A female professional dancer. See alma, ghawazee, nautch-girl, etc.
Hence A pert or saucy girl or woman; one who is too bold or forward; a minx.
Used as a courtesy title before the surname or full name of a woman, especially a married woman, in a French-speaking area:  Madame Cartier; Madame Jacqueline Cartier.
The wife or widow of a duke; also, a lady who has the sovereignty of a duchy in her own right.
The wife of an earl in the British peerage, or of a count in the Continental nobility; also, a lady possessed of the same dignity in her own right. See the Note under count.
a lady of the queen's household, appointed to wait upon or attend the queen.
In the East Indies, a princess or lady of high rank.
Chinese lady palm with more slender stems and finer sheath fibers than Rhapis excelsa
Chinese lady palm with more slender stems and finer sheath fibers than Rhapis excelsa
Chinese lady palm with more slender stems and finer sheath fibers than Rhapis excelsa
a lady fern with deeply cut leaf segments; found in the Rocky Mountains
a lady fern with deeply cut leaf segments; found in the Rocky Mountains
Lit., my lady; hence (as used on the Continent), an English noblewoman or gentlewoman.
Lady; a lady; -- a title formerly given to noble ladies who held a barony in their own right.
Same as lady's slipper.
A woman who holds the chief authority in an abbey, nunnery, or similar institution: more properly called lady superior.
A lady's-maid, or under lady's-maid.
A cruciferous plant, Cardamine pratensis. Also called cuckoo-flower. Commonly called lady-smock.
A Portuguese title of courtesy given to a lady; Mrs.; Madam; also, a lady.
A Spanish title of courtesy given to a lady; Mrs.; Madam; also, a lady.
A gay lady; a beautiful lady.
A lady's waiting-maid.
the queen or lady of May, in old May games.
A lady's maid; a chambermaid.
My lady; -- a term of address in Italian formerly used as the equivalent of Madame, but for which Signora is now substituted. Sometimes introduced into English.
A lady's gown.
A lady's skirt made of any stiff material; latterly, a hoop skirt.
A lady who wears a kerchief.

a leguminous herb of Europe and Asia (Anthyllis vulneraria), with cloverlike heads of red or yellow flowers, once used as a remedy for renal disorders, and also to stop the flow of blood from wounds; lady's-fingers.
an altar in a lady chapel.
the court of a lady of the manor.
a lady having jurisdiction of a manor; also, the wife of a manor lord.
A little lady; -- applied by the writers of Queen Elizabeth's time, in the abbreviated form Lakin, to the Virgin Mary.
A nun of the Order of Our lady of Mount Carmel.
A maid or female servant who dresses a lady and waits on her in her own room; a lady's-maid.

Formerly, one who attended a lady to public places as a guide or protector; a duenna; now, more especially, a married woman who, in accordance with the rules of etiquette, accompanies a young unmarried woman to public places or social entertainments.
A damsel; a young lady: as, a ‘beautiful donzella.’
The larger yellow lady's-slipper, Cypripedium hirsutum.
The condition and manners of an affected “fine lady.”
The reed canary-grass, Phalaris arundinacea. Also lady's-laces, bride's-laces.
The heart'sease or lady's-thumb, Polygonum Persicaria.
An Italian marchioness; a lady having the rank of marchioness.
A French or Italian form of the English my lady: applied on the continent of Europe to titled Englishwomen. Also spelled milady.
The stemless lady's-slipper, Cypripedium acaule.
The nodding lady's-tresses, Gyrostachis cernua, so called from the spiral arrangement of the flowers.
A fair woman; a fine lady.
A small boot; a lady's boot.
Anciently, a chamber; a lodging room; esp., a lady's private apartment.
The queen or lady of the May, in old May-games.
See lady's slipper.
The name of a game, apparently like “my lady's toilet.”
The lady's-cushion, Armeria vulgaris.
A South-African Dutch form of the East Indian ayah, a nurse; a lady's-maid.
A bumpkin; a boor; a slattern: as, she's a lady! she's no bush-scrubber. See scrubber.
A native nurse for children; also, a lady's maid.
The lady-bird.
A lady.
A small room, esp. if pleasant, or elegantly furnished, to which a lady may retire to be alone, or to receive intimate friends; a lady's bedroom; a lady's (or sometimes a gentleman's) private room.
A lady's girdle.
A court lady.
An effeminate person; a lady's man.
A chambermaid; a lady's-maid.
The Nigella Damascena, or ragged-lady, also N. sativa, the seeds of which are used in the East as a condiment, and medicinally as a carminative and diuretic.
A lady of rank; the feminine of the title khan.
The court of a lady of the manor.
The wren: a contraction of Our Lady's hen. See hen.
The acts or arts of a lady-killer; assiduous gallantry.
A plant, Our Lady's bedstraw, Galium verum.
The thrift, Armeria vulgaris, a maritime plant with a dense cushion-like growth: also called sea-cushion. Several other plants have sometimes been named lady's-cushion.
The wife of a landgrave; a lady of the rank of a landgrave.
A lady of fashion.
A lady of a court appointed to serve or attend a queen, princess, or royal duchess.
A person of good breeding; a lady or a gentleman.
genus of tropical American orchid species often included in genus Cypripedium or Paphiopedilum and Selenipedium: lady slippers
genus of tropical American orchid species often included in genus Cypripedium or Paphiopedilum and Selenipedium: lady slippers
lady fingers enclosing Bavarian cream
In India, a European lady; the mistress of a household: so called by native servants.
A lady's outer garment, -- of varying fashion.
An outer garment for men or women, originally of fur, or lined with fur; a lady's or child's long outer garment, made of silk or other fabric.
a lady who enjoys the highest rank of the ladies in the service of the English sovereign (when a queen), and is supposed to have the care her robes.
A lady; mistress.
the lady's comb.
A lady in honor of whom persons or a company are invited to drink; -- so called because toasts were formerly put into the liquor, as a great delicacy.
A lady at a ball, who, either from choice, or because not asked to dance, remains a spectator.

The Impatiens balsamina, a familiar flowering annual, of Eastern origin, cultivated in many varieties, often called garden-balsam, and in the United States lady's-slipper; also, the native European species, I. Noli-me-tangere, and the American I. fulva. See Impatiens and jewel-weed.
A genus of grasses, commonly called quaking-grass, maidenhair-grass, or lady's-hair.
A young lady just “come out” in society.
A term loosely applied to many kinds of insects, commonly with certain distinctive additions, as May-bug, lady-bug, land-bugs (Geocorisæ), water-bugs (Hydrocorisæ), etc.
A flat basket or frail for figs, etc.; hence, a lady's flat workbasket, reticule, or hand bag; -- often written caba.
A chambermaid; a lady's-maid.
A private secretary to the lady superior of a convent.
A female castellan; the lady of the castle or château. See chatelain.
A similar veil or kerchief worn by a knight pendent from his helmet, as if bestowed by his lady; hence, any favor of like character worn at a tournament, etc.
A gentleman who attends or escorts a lady in public.
In some parts of the United States, the common persicary, peachwort, lady's-thumb, or smartweed, Polygonum Persicaria.
A lady-love; a sweetheart: often used as a term of endearment.
Maid Marian, the lady of the morris-dance.
In music, an evening song; especially, such a song sung by a lover at the window of his lady.

A name given to various things of a presumably coquettish or attractive nature: a small becoming bonnet fashionable about the middle of the nineteenth century; a lady's cap with ribbons that tied under the chin on one side with ‘kissing-strings’; a short lock of hair curled in front of each ear, etc. The name is also given to the wild pansy. See kiss-me.
A man who busies himself with affairs which properly belong to women.
courtesy towards women

A kind of loose robe or gown tied with a sash, worn as a traditional outer garment by Japanese women and men. Women may wear it with a broad sash called an obi, having a large bow in the back. At present (1998), most Japanese wear it only at home or on ceremonial occasions, western-style clothing being more common in the workplace.
The right of women to vote; exercise of the franchise by women.
One of an association of priests or religious women who have offered themselves to the service of the church. There are three such associations of priests, and one of women, called oblates.
4. A head-dress worn in the later middle ages, and throughout the seventeenth century, by both men and women. That worn by women was broad at the top, with projecting corners, like ears.
A muslin wrapper for the head and the lower part of the face, worn by Turkish and Armenian women when they go abroad.
a boat race in which the crews are composed of a number of pairs, usually of men and women.
Persons of doubtful reputation; esp., women who are kept as mistresses, though not public prostitutes; demireps.
A women who plays in comedy.
In the Middle Ages, a gown or basque of which the body was close fitting, worn by both men and women.
A public nursery, where the young children of poor women are cared for during the day, while their mothers are at work.
That part of a large house, among the ancients, exclusively appropriated to women.
a small net that some women wear over their hair to keep it in place.
A supposed primitive state of society, in which all the women of a tribe were held in common.
Purity; chastity; -- a term applied mostly to women, but becoming uncommon in usage.
A garment varying in form and use at different times, and worn both by men and women.
A mixture of soot and other ingredients, used by Egyptian and other Eastern women to darken the edges of the eyelids.
A gallant who captivates the hearts of women.
A printed cloth garment resembling a skirt or kilt, worn as the principle garment by both men and women in Polynesia, especialy in Samoa; called also pareu.
A long outer garment formerly worn by men and women, as well as by soldiers as part of their uniform.
A sentimental motion picture that appeals particularly to women.  See flick, n., movie.
The green sickness; an anæmic disease of young women, characterized by a greenish or grayish yellow hue of the skin, weakness, palpitation, etc.
A fabric with a silk warp and a wool or cotton weft, so woven as to throw the silk on the face: used for umbrellas and women's dress-goods.
A garment, worn by Moro women, formed of a long piece of cloth, sewed together at the ends, which is wrapped about the body in various ways.
The women of a family or party. Compare womankind.
A sort of sling or support by means of which the native Australian women carry their children on their backs.
A room or ward in a hospital or other public institution where women are cared for during parturition.
A nose-ring worn by East Indian women as a badge of widowhood.
In the Philippine Islands, a knot of hair held together by a comb, worn by Tagalog women.
A loose gown (or a roll of cotton for the purpose) worn by native women in Egypt under the habara or cloak.
A kind of semilunar knife used by Eskimo women.
A jacket worn by Eskimo men and women. See jumper.
One who has an aversion to women in general; a misogynist.
One who kills women. See manqueller.
The exercise of the electoral franchise by women.
The veil worn by Moslem women in public—that is, when not in their own apartments.
A loose full gown worn by women: so named from its general resemblance to that considered characteristic of “Mother Hubbard” in the rimes of “Mother Goose.”
A smooth, strong, rich silk, originally manufactured at Padua, used for garments of both women and men in the eighteenth century; also, a garment made of this material.
In civil and Scots law, the crime of stealing men, women, or children, formerly punishable with death.
A loose gown formerly worn by men and women to protect their clothes when having the hair powdered; a dressing-gown.
A man devoted to a life of pleasure and sensuality, especially in his relation to women; a debauchee; a rake.
A kind of false birth fabled to be produced by Dutch women from sitting over their stoves (Johnson)′ , hence, an abortive scheme or attempt.
A many-colored wrap or rectangular piece of woolen cloth used by the Indian women of Bolivia for carrying their children on the back. Compare atado.
A shirt; a chemise; specifically, a waist made of piña, white or dyed, embroidered, and with loose sleeves, worn by the native women of the Philippine Islands.
A long-term, intimate, sometimes discreetly sexual relationship between two women.
A loose, usually black robe worn by Muslim women, especially in Arabic-speaking regions, covering the body from head to toe and often worn with a headscarf and veil.

A psychophysiological disorder usually occurring in young women that is characterized by an abnormal fear of becoming obese, a distorted self-image, a persistent unwillingness to eat, and severe weight loss. It is often accompanied by self-induced vomiting, excessive exercise, malnutrition, amenorrhea, and other physiological changes.
A rectangular woolen or linen cloak worn by men and women in ancient Greece.
A synthetic drug analogue of pyrophosphate that acts primarily on bone to inhibit its resorption and is used to treat and prevent osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.
The traditional dress of Vietnamese women, consisting of a long tunic that is slit on the sides and worn over loose trousers.
A long cotton outer garment, usually white, traditionally worn by Muslim women.
A long dress with a high collar and slit skirt, traditionally worn by Chinese women.
A loose, usually black robe worn by Muslim women that covers the body from head to toe.
A loose, usually black or light blue robe that is worn by Muslim women, especially in Afghanistan, and that covers the body from head to toe.
A familiar name for an aunt. In the southern United States a familiar term applied to aged negro women.
An outer petticoat worn by Basque and Spanish women.
A small cap, usually made of muslin or lace and ribbons, worn at breakfast by married women.
Literally, the bed in which a woman gives birth to a child; hence, the act of bringing forth a child or the state of being in labor; parturition: as, “women in child-bed,” Arbuthnot, Aliments.
A place where poor women may leave their children to be taken care of during the day, while the mothers are at work.
An outer garment worn by Maltese women, usually made of silk. See the extracts.

A cap or head-dress formerly worn by elderly women, formed like two crescents conjoined, and, by means of wire, made to stand out from the cushion on which the hair was dressed. Its name seems to come from the resemblance of its sides to wings.
An anemic disease of young women, giving a greenish tinge to the complexion; chlorosis.
In medicine and surgery, the science of the diseases peculiar to women.
A stiff flaring collar wired to stand up at the back of the head, worn by men and women in the 16th and early 17th century.
A sudden brief sensation of heat, often over the entire body, caused by a transient dilation of the blood vessels of the skin and experienced by some women during menopause.

An abnormal curvature of the spine that is primarily manifested as a rounded hump in the upper back. Typically affecting older women, the curvature is a result of collapse of the spinal column, caused by osteoporosis.
Judaism   A partition erected in the seating section of an Orthodox synagogue to prevent the mixing of men and women.
A garment consisting of a length of printed cloth wrapped about the waist that is worn by men and women in Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Pacific islands.
Creative, often sexual yearning, love, or desire: "The new playful eros means that impulses and modes from other spheres enter the relations between men and women”  ( Herbert Gold).
A support, such as a hoop, worn beneath a skirt to extend it horizontally from the waist, used by European women in the 16th and 17th centuries.
A garment consisting of a rectangular piece of printed cloth worn especially in Polynesia by men and women as a wraparound skirt.
Loose-fitting trousers worn in the Far East by men and women. Often used in the plural.

The custom of marriage of a man to his wife's sister or sisters, usually after the wife has died or proved sterile.

Relationship by marriage (as between a husband and his wife's blood relations, or between a wife and her husband's blood relations); -- in contradistinction to consanguinity, or relationship by blood; -- followed by with, to, or between.

A consort, husband or wife; a companion; a fere.
A great rani; a princess in India or the wife of a maharaja.
The state of being engaged, pledged or occupied; specif., a pledge to take some one as husband or wife.
The wife of a margrave.

A nobleman of England ranking below a marquis, and above a viscount. The rank of an earl corresponds to that of a count (comte) in France, and graf in Germany. Hence the wife of an earl is still called countess. See count.
The wife or widow of an elector in the old German empire.
The division of a shield palewise, or by a vertical line, esp. for the purpose of putting side by side the arms of husband and wife. See Impale, 3.
The wife of a marquis; a marchioness.
A man whose wife is unfaithful; the husband of an adulteress.
the life estate which a husband has in the lands of his deceased wife, which by the common law takes effect where he has had issue by her, born alive, and capable of inheriting the lands.
A helper; a companion; specifically, a wife.
A wife; a helpmate.

Domestic squabbling; the quarreling of man and wife.
In primitive society where laws of exogamy exist, that tribe from which a member of a certain tribe must choose his wife.
The dowry which a wife brings to her husband by marriage.

A man who has lost his wife by death.

A married person, husband or wife; either one of a married pair.
A son of one's husband or wife by a former marriage.

Greek Mythology   The wife of Orpheus, whom he failed to rescue from Hades when he looked back at her and so violated the command of Pluto on their journey back to the upper world of the living.

The state of being monogamous; having one wife at a time.
Single marriage; marriage with but one person, husband or wife, at the same time; -- opposed to <contr>polygamy</contr>. Also, one marriage only during life; -- opposed to <contr>deuterogamy</contr>.
A married couple; a man and wife.
A husband or a wife.
The more ancient of the two great epic poems in Sanskrit. The hero and heroine are Rama and his wife Sita.
A wife; -- in allusion to Eve, as made out of Adam's rib.

A wife; a married woman.

One of a Christian sect which originated in Arabia in the latter part of the fourth century, who denied the perpetual virginity of Mary, holding that she was the real wife of Joseph, and had children by him after the birth of Jesus. Also called Antimarian.
In law and heraldry, a husband: as, baron and feme, husband and wife.

Common possession or enjoyment; the holding or sharing of interests, possessions, or privileges in common by two or more individuals: as, a community of goods; community of interests between husband and wife.

In Scots law, that part of a man's movable succession which he is entitled to dispose of by testament, or that which remains of the movables over and above what is due to the wife and children. Sometimes dead man's part.
The group comprising a husband and wife and their dependent children, constituting a fundamental unit in the organization of society.
Particularly A mate in marriage; a spouse; a husband or wife.
A woman having real estate which she leases to a tenant or tenants.
A beloved person; an object of affectionate interest, as a sweetheart or a husband or wife: often also used in address as a term of endearment.
More specifically, the power of a Roman husband over his wife: as, in manu (of a woman), under the marital authority.
One who has but one (living and undivorced) wife, as opposed to a bigamist or a polygamist.
A principal Egyptian god, personifying the power of good and the sunlight, united in history and in worship in a sacred triad with Isis as his wife and Horus as their child.
In the early church, and in the medieval church, a priest's wife, especially one living apart from her husband; a priest's widow; later, a priest's concubine.

The act of retaking, as of one who has escaped after arrest; reprisal; the retaking of one's own goods, chattels, wife, or children, without force or violence, from one who has taken them and who wrongfully detains them.
The wife of a squire.

Among the orthodox Jews, the period of mourning for a parent, brother, sister, husband, or wife, consisting of seven days. At the burial the principal mourners tear their garments; afterward they retire to their homes, take off their shoes, and sit upon the floor for seven days, spending the time in prayer and liturgical exercises.
In law: Ownership: as, the title was not in the husband, but in his wife; her title was subject to encumbrance.
The state of a man whose wife is dead, or of a woman whose husband is dead, and who has not married again: generally applied to the state or condition of being a widow.

A man or young man; a fellow; -- usually contrasted with <contr>gals</contr> or <contr>girls</contr> .

A fop or exquisite, characterized by affected refinements of dress, speech, manners, and gait, and a serious mien; hence, by an easy extension, and with less of contempt, a man given to excessive refinement of fashion in dress.
A man engaged in business. See Usage Note at man.
A well-mannered and considerate man with high standards of proper behavior. See Usage Note at lady.
A wise man; a man of gravity and wisdom; particularly, a man venerable for years, and known as a man of sound judgment and prudence; a grave philosopher.

A name given to a hypothetical ape-like man, or speechless primitive man, intermediate in character between the highest anthropoid apes and human beings, and conjectured by Haeckel to have been the progenitor of the human race.

Specifically, a man enlisted for service in the army; a newly enlisted soldier.
A man of social authority and dignity; a lord; a master; a gentleman; -- in this sense usually spelled sire.
A boy or man who attends in a stable; a groom; a hostler.
A wencher; a lewd man.
A whoremaster; a lecher; a man who frequents the society of whores.
an enlisted man responsible for the upkeep of small arms and machine guns etc.
A piece or man in the game of checkers.
A man skilled in divinity; a theologian: as, a great divine; “the Revelation of St. John the Divine.”

One who practises the art of healing disease and of preserving health; a prescriber of remedies for sickness and disease; specifically, a person licensed by some competent authority, such as a medical college, to treat diseases and pre scribe remedies for them; a doctor; a medical man.
A man of straw. See man of straw , under man.
In mining, the man who uses a tubber. Also called beele-man.
A man who practises obi. Also obea-man, obeah-man.
A man of literary culture; a man of letters; a literary man.

The material and spiritual universe, as distinguished from the Creator; the system of things of whieh man forms a part; creation, especially that part of it which more immediately surrounds man and affects his senses, as mountains, seas, rivers, woods, etc.: as, the beauties of nature; in a restricted sense, whatever is produced without artificial aid, and exists unchanged by man, and is thus opposed to art.

That premise which contains the major term. It its the first proposition of a regular syllogism; as: No unholy person is qualified for happiness in heaven [the major]. Every man in his natural state is unholy [minor]. Therefore, no man in his natural state is qualified for happiness in heaven [conclusion or inference].
The great world; that part of the universe which is exterior to man; -- contrasted with microcosm, or man. See microcosm.

A perpetual or continuing right which a man and his heirs have to an estate; an estate which a man has by descent as heir to another, or which he may transmit to another as his heir; an estate derived from an ancestor to an heir in course of law.
A ladies' man who is especially adept at inventing effective introductory phrases (pick-up lines) to gain a woman's attention.
See Portuguese man-of-war under man-of-war and also see Physalia.
Same as man of action.
The early orchis, Orchis muscula of England, so called from the color and shape of the tubers. Also called dead-man's-hand.
In mining, a bottom-man; a man who puts mine-cars on a cage.
A man; a fellow; especially a man who has a fad: as, a fresh-air sport.
A wise man; a native priest or medicine-man. [New Zealand.]
Same as tongue-man.
A word occurring only in the proverb “Better be an old man's darling than a young man's warling,” Camden, Remains.
A man endowed with uncommon vigor of mind; a man of superior intellectual faculties and creativity.
A man who is insane; a distracted man; a lunatic; a crazy person.
A kind of car used for transporting miners up and down the steeply inclined shafts of some mines on Lake Superior. Compare man-engine.
One who deals in goods for men's wear. Also called man-huckster.
An enlisted man belonging to a man-of-war.
The rate of work done normally by one man in a given time.—2. A motor utilizing the force of a man in driving machinery.
The worship of man; undue reverence or extreme adulation paid to a man.
A man of the Isle of Man. See Manx, n., 2.
Plural of man.
Same as old-man cactus. See Cereus.
See man.
A man who sells pies; also, a man who makes pies.
A man armed with a rifle; a man skilled in shooting with the rifle; military, formerly, a member of a body armed with the rifle when most of the infantry had muskets.
A man detailed to assist in working the sails of a man-of-war in action.
Same as sallee-man, 2.
A man who presides over or teaches a school; a man whose business it is to keep school.
A man; a laboring man.
One of a number of boys on board a man-of-war appointed to attend at the gangway and hand the man-ropes to an officer entering or leaving the ship.
The habit of considering everything as subordinate to man, or of considering things in relation to man and his needs and destiny.

A man who has a crucial, often hazardous role in the forefront of an enterprise: "[He] has traditionally been the administration's point man on affirmative-action issues, making frequent public appearances to present and clarify the administration's views”  ( Christian Science Monitor).
A man who wears an apron; a laboring man or workman; a waiter or bar-tender.
A man skilled in an art or in the arts; especially, a learned man; a scholar.
A warrior; a hero; a man of valor; in later use, a poetic term for man.
A rag man, or a man made of rags—that is, a scarecrow made of old garments.
A man who was born in or is a citizen of England; in a broad sense, a man of the English race who preserves his distinctive racial character, wherever he resides.
Same as fasting-man.
On a man-of-war, a man stationed at the foremast to keep the ropes, etc., in order.
A man,, particularly a bold, strong, vigorous man.
A man employed to do various kinds of work; a general-utility man; specifically, a skilled laborer who serves as assistant to a mechanic or artisan.
A man employed in a laundry; a man engaged in the business of washing and ironing clothes: as, a Chinese laundryman.
Plural of man-of-war.
A beginner; a novice. See Usage Note at man.
Plural of man-child.
Plural of man-at-arms.
A woman who speaks on behalf of another or others. See Usage Note at man.
A man-midwife; a medical practitioner who attends women in childbirth.
A man of fire or spirit; a fiery spark; a gay, showy man; a rake.
A learned man; a man of letters; a scholar; a writer or author; originally, a man who could read, an attainment at one time confined chiefly to ecclesiastics.
Offensive Slang   Used as a disparaging term for an effeminate man, especially a homosexual man.
early man of late Pleistocene; skull resembles that of Neanderthal man but with smaller cranial capacity; found in Java
Slang   A young man who is the sexual partner of an older man.
modern man and extinct immediate ancestors of man
former genus of primitive man; now Homo soloensis: comprises Solo man
modern man and extinct immediate ancestors of man
former genus of primitive man; now Homo soloensis: comprises Solo man
The male corresponding to <contr>mermaid</contr>; a sea man, or man fish.

a man who makes or deals in millinery, that occupation having been at one time predominantly performed by women; hence, contemptuously, a man who is busied with trifling occupations or embellishments.
A brave warrior; a man of military experience and skill, or a man of distinguished valor; -- used by way of emphasis or distinction.
A brave man; a man of valor.
A man who plies for hire on rivers, lakes, or canals, or in harbors, in distinction from a seaman who is engaged on the high seas; a man who manages fresh-water craft; a boatman; a ferryman.
A laboring man; a man who earns his daily support by manual labor.
A man slave, or a man bound to service without wages. Also improperly written bondsman.
Deportment of behavior in social life; manners, especially good manners: as, good breeding (politeness); a man of no breeding (that is, a very ill-bred man).
A man; a robust, strong, or hardy man; a fellow.

A member of the clergy; a man in holy orders; a man regularly authorized to preach the gospel and administer ordinances according to the rules of any particular denomination of Christians. In England the term is commonly restricted to ministers of the established church.
A wealthy man; especially, one who makes a vulgar use or display of his wealth; a rich and vulgar man; a chuff.
The devil's-apron, Laminaria digitata. Also called dead-man's-toe.

A descendant of Ishmael, Abraham's son, who, as is related in Genesis (xxi. 14), was driven into the wilderness with his mother, Hagar. His twelve sons were “princes” or heads of tribes. The Arabs regard him as their ancestor.
A man of letters; a learned or literary man.

A hole through which a man may enter a sewer, drain, cesspool, or the like, for cleaning or repairing; in steam-boilers, hot-water tanks, keirs, etc., a hole formed in the shell, through which a man may enter to the interior for cleaning, inspection, or repairs.
A man who sports; specifically, a man who practises field-sports, especially hunting or fishing, usually for pleasure and in a legitimate manner.
A man who travels in search of employment: so called because he carries his swag, or bundle of clothes, blanket, etc. Also swags-man, swagger.
In athletics, the man who has the farthest distance to go in a race, or the greatest handicap to overcome; a scratch-man.
Nautical, a man stationed to do duty in a top. In a man-of-war the topmen are divided into fore-, main-, and mizzen-topmen. Also topsman.
A British sailor; a man-of-war's-man.
The hero of the book of that name in the Old Testament; the prototypical patient man.
a man with a chauvinistic belief in the inferiority of women
A man whose business is to extinguish fires in towns; a member of a fire company.
A man of more appearance of wit than reality.
A man who delivers the mail. A male mail carrier.
A man who has authority to act, within certain limits, as master of the house; a steward; also, a chief minister or officer.
An uxorious, effeminate, or spiritless man.
A man.
a man's high tasseled boot.
A man born in Ireland or of the Irish race; an Hibernian.
a man specially skilled in any art, handicraft, or trade, or who is an overseer, foreman, or employer.
The killer; the man appointed to kill the bull in bullfights; a bullfighter; a toreador.
A man engaged in rafting.
A man; sometimes implying clumsiness.
A man who practices massage.
A man who manages, or waits on, an engine.
rent paid for the privilege of building on another man's land.
a conspicuous or eminent man.
an easement or servitude by which a man has the right to have the water flowing from his house fall on the land of his neighbor.
One whose employment is to remove dirt and refuse; a garbage man.
Master; sir; -- a Turkish title of respect, applied esp. to a state official or man of learning, as one learned in the law, but often simply as the courtesy title of a gentleman.
The act of eloping; secret departure; -- said of a woman and a man, one or both, who run away from their homes for marriage or for cohabitation.
A man who carries logs.
A little man; a dwarf; a pygmy; a manakin.
A little man.
A youth; a young man; a juvenile.
A man who deals in lace.
A man-of-war having two gun decks.
an easement or servitude by which one man has a right to convey water in pipes through or over the estate of another.
A “man” or piece used in the game of draughts.
A man who attends a dray.
A man who carries or takes care of a light.
A man rope at the side of a ladder.
A boy or man that carried a link or torch to light passengers.
A man whose occupation is to make malt.

a contrivance by which miners ascend or descend in a shaft. It consists of a series of landings in the shaft and an equal number of shelves on a vertical rod which has an up and down motion equal to the distance between the successive landings. A man steps from a landing to a shelf and is lifted or lowered to the next landing, upon which he them steps, and so on, traveling by successive stages.

a bullet which will produce a sufficient shock to stop a soldier advancing in a charge; specif., a small-caliber bullet so modified as to expand when striking the human body, producing a severe wound which is also difficult to treat medically. Types of bullets called hollow-nosed bullets, soft-nosed bullets and hollow-point bullets are classed as man-stopping. The dumdum bullet or dumdum is another well-known variety. Such bullets were originally designed for wars with savage tribes.
One who is given to intemperance or bacchanalian excesses; a man habitually lewd; a libertine.
A man employed in decoying wild fowl.
A half man.
According to the Gnostics, an agent or one employed by the Supreme Being to create the material universe and man.
A reckless, furious man; a person urged by furious passions, and regardless of consequence; a wild ruffian.
Division into two; especially, the division of a class into two subclasses opposed to each other by contradiction, as the division of the term man into white and not white.
A covetous, sordid man; a miser; a niggard.
A man who is skilled in traveling upon ice, as among glaciers.
A man in private station, as distinguished from one holding a public office.
The man who heaves the lead.
A man given to lewdness; one addicted, in an excessive degree, to the indulgence of sexual desire, or to illicit sexual relations with women; also called letch and lech.
People; a nation; a man.
A man of extreme enmity or evil intentions.
A man that wears the horns; a cuckold.
A man who attends at the counter of a shop to sell goods.
A boy or man of any age or station.
A king of Lydia who flourished in the 6th century b. c., and was renowned for his vast wealth; hence, a common appellation for a very rich man.
A man who keeps or takes care of a dairy.
A man, or body of men, stationed to protect or control a person or position; a watch; a sentinel.
A man who lets horses and carriages for hire.
A wise man; a physician, esp. a Mohammedan.
A man who earns his living by handicraft; a handicraftsman.
A man skilled or employed in handcraft.
The wives, concubines, female relatives, and servants occupying such a place.
A man engaged in harvesting.
A person hired to murder or physically attack another; a hit man.
A head or leading man, especially of a village community.
The man at the helm; a steersman.
A cotquean; a man who intermeddles with women's concerns.
The liberty or right of pasture in the forest or in the grounds of another man.
An illustrious man, supposed to be exalted, after death, to a place among the gods; a demigod, as Hercules.
A slanderer working for political purposes to damage the reputation of an opponent; a hatchet man.
A man who carries a hod; a mason's tender.
A little man; a dwarf; a manikin.
A rider on horseback; one skilled in the management of horses; a mounted man.
A man of the same race or family; one related by blood.
a man who takes advantage of women
any one of several species of blood-sucking leeches, which, in moist, tropical regions, live on land, and are often troublesome to man and beast.
A man who lives or serves on land; -- opposed to <contr>seaman</contr>.
A man of coarse nature and manners; an awkward fellow; an ill-bred person; a boor.
A man whose business is to drive a coach or carriage.
A stern man.
The man who manipulates a grip.
A male attendant of a bridegroom at his wedding; -- the chief attendant is also called the best man; -- the correlative of <contr>bridesmaid</contr>.
A short, thick man; a dwarf.
A wretched or unfortunate man.
A south American tick of the genus Amblyomma. There are several species, very troublesome to man and beast.
A Turkish man-of-war.
A man whose employment is to drive, or to convey goods in, a car or car.
An adventurer; -- a term of contempt for a Northern man seeking private gain or political advancement in the southern part of the United States after the Civil War (1865).
A man who drives a cart; a teamster.
A man who is amorously and gallantly attentive to women.
A man who digs chalk.
A man or boy; a youth; a fellow.
A man who becomes sponsor for a child at baptism, and makes himself a surety for its Christian training and instruction. Correlative of <contr>godmother</contr>.
A man.
A man who rows a gondola.
One who has the care or guardianship of a young man; a tutor; a guardian.
A man of elevated rank or station; a nobleman. In Spain, a nobleman of the first rank, who may be covered in the king's presence.
A man learned in the civil law; an expert in juridical science; a professor of jurisprudence; a jurist.
In Bunyan's ‘Holy War,’ one of the warriors of Diabolus (the Devil) in his attack on Mansoul (man's soul).
The opinion in moral theology that where the reasons for either of two opposed courses of action are equally balanced, a man may use his liberty to follow either.
A man engaged in signaling moving railway-trains during fogs.
A man shipped before the mast; a forecastleman.
A man placed in charge of a ship's gangway when in port.
The governor or head-man of a village or small town in the Philippines.
In cricket, a man whose duty it is to keep a cricket-ground in condition for play. Also groundsman.
A man skilled in representing topography by means of hachures or contours on an engraved plate.
A man engaged in raising and moving buildings by means of jack-screws and rollers moving upon prepared wooden ways.
In base-ball, a base-man, short-stop, or pitcher when he is fielding the ball.
Specifically, a bookkeeper employed in inns to run up, increase, or inflame the bills of customers: called the inflamer of reckonings. Jonson introduces a man of this kind in “The New Inn.”
A familiar name for an enlisted man in the navy.
A shaman or medicine-man of the Australian aborigines.
A brother-in-law; a male relative of a man who, after the latter′ s death, has the right, and the duty, to marry his widow.
A man employed in the life-saving service.
The head man of a village in parts of India and central Asia.
A deity regarded as being in form or origin or in other respects a man.
A native head-man, in the Tamil districts of Ceylon; a chief.
A man who operates a motor; specifically, one who operates a railway motor.
An effeminate fellow; a ladies' man.
A man who delivers to subscribers the successive numbers of a subscription-book that is issued in numbers.
Among the Maoris, a white man; a foreigner.
In Ireland, a man who lived in the English pale.
A man who does the domestic work which is carried on in pantries.
In French and British Guiana, a witch-doctor; a soothsayer; a medicine-man; a conjurer. See piache.
A medicine-man or witch-doctor among the Indians of Central and South America. Also peai. See peaiman.
In Tasmania, a man who cuts Huon pine and brings it down to the coast.
A man who looks after ponies, or has charge of ponies in a caravan, etc.
Mil., a rear-rank man.
An idle, and frequently dissolute, man who lives on remittances from his home.
The Portuguese man-of-war, Physalia pelagica.
A man who wears soap-locks; hence, a low fellow; a young rowdy or rough: as, “the soap-locks of the Bowery.”
A sea-bladder; a Portuguese man-of-war, Physalia.
A technical term of the scholastic philosophy, signifying the innate principle in the moral consciousness of every man, which directs him to good and restrains him from evil.
In forestry, a man who records or tallies the measurements of logs as they are called by the scaler.
Short for tambourine: referring to an end-man in a negro minstrel-show who plays on that instrument.
The worship by primitive man of wild or venomous beasts.
The smallest and weakest of a litter of pigs, puppies, or the like; a runt. [New Eng.] —2. Hence a man who is stunted, physically and mentally.
An old name for a waister on a British man-of-war.
A term used in the late South African republics to denote any white man in the country who is not a Boer.
A man who patrols irrigation ditches to keep them in order or repair. See ditch-rider. Also zangero.
A man ready in the quotation of texts, or too strict in adherence to the letter of texts.
A man who attends to the attiring of another; a dresser, especially in a theater; a valet.
A swift steam man-of-war, especially designed to overtake and capture torpedo-boats.
One who teaches others in some trade or mechanical art; a man who instructs boys in some kind of handicraft.
A man employed on a railway-train, as a brakeman or a porter.
A man belonging to a tribe; a member of a particular tribe, or of the same tribe as the person speaking or referred to.
A man who prepares tripe and hawks it about.
In whale-fishing, a man whose place in a whale-boat is near the tub containing the whale-line, and whose business is to see that no entanglement of the line takes place.
A man who collects tolls at a turnpike or toll-gate.
One who vaunts; a boaster; a braggart; a man given to vain ostentation.
A man summoned under a venire facias for jury service.
The act of putting to death every twentieth man.
A man of Wapping, a district of London along the Thames, near the Tower.
A man of Wapping, London.
A man who washes clothes, etc.
One who wenches; a lewd man.
A man.
A man employed on or about a wharf; one performing or having charge of work on a wharf.
The man at the wheel of a vessel; a steersman.
A man who busies himself about household affairs or woman's work.
A man who puts up and looks after wires, as for the telegraph, telephone, or electric lighting.
A wild man of the woods; a satyr or faun. Representations of woodwoses often appear in heraldry as supporters.
a male child (a familiar term of address to a boy)
A male child.
A male child nursed at the same breast as another, or reared by the same person, but not the offspring of the same parents.
a male exhibiting or characterized by machismo

a male person

A lad; a male sweetheart.
one of the two male reproductive glands; a testis; -- usually spelled ballock, and usually used in the plural.
A young bull, or any male of the ox kind.
a teenager or a young adult male
A male attendant on a tennis court who collects the ball when it is out of play.
One of whom a fee or estate is held; the male owner of feudal land
a young male shop assistant
a male child (a familiar term of address to a boy)
a male child (a familiar term of address to a boy)
A horseman; a knight; a gallant young man.
Archaic   A male ancestor; a forefather.
the male of species Equus caballus
an adult male who shaves
a male sworn (usually by a ceremony involving the mingling of blood) to treat another as his brother
a male child (a familiar term of address to a boy)
One of the essential male genital glands which secrete the semen.
someone who engages in anal copulation (especially a male who engages in anal copulation with another male)
someone who engages in anal copulation (especially a male who engages in anal copulation with another male)

The condition or character of being female or male; the physiological, functional, and psychological differences that distinguish the female and the male. See Usage Note at gender.
orchid having both male and female flowers in the same raceme; when a sensitive projection at the base of the column of the male flower is touched the pollen is suddenly ejected
someone who engages in anal copulation (especially a male who engages in anal copulation with another male)
orchid having both male and female flowers in the same raceme; when a sensitive projection at the base of the column of the male flower is touched the pollen is suddenly ejected
A male person castrated for the purpose of improving his voice for singing; an artificial, or male, soprano.
A person who delivers the mail; -- also called a letter carrier. A male mail carrier is also called a mailman.
A male godchild.
a person with a compulsive desire to expose the genitals; -- usually a male.
A male person having another living being so far subject to his will, that he can, in the main, control his or its actions; -- formerly used with much more extensive application than now.
A drake; the male of Anas boschas.
a male child.
In ornithology, having two male mates.
A paternal name; a name derived from one's father or from one's ancestors in the male line.
A German male singing society or chorus.
In a lathe, the male screw which moves the back-center backward and forward; the tail-piece.
The male mistlethrush.
A male sea-monster of human form; a sort of merman.
The male widgeon or goldenhead, Mareca penelope.

A small song bird (Sialia sialis), very common in the United States, and, in the north, one of the earliest to arrive in spring. The male is blue, with the breast reddish. It is related to the European robin.
the male of a variety of the zebu, or Indian ox, considered sacred by the Hindus.
A male friend who attends upon a bridegroom and bride at their marriage; the “best man.”
A milliner of the male sex; especially, one who undertakes the manufacture of women's bonnets, etc., employing others to do the work.
A common European fern, Aspidium Oreopteris, closely allied to the male-fern, A. Filix-mas.
A male teacher of music.
The so-called male coffee-berry.
A male servant, or man-servant.
A male servant; a menial.
A male pronucleus. See masculonucleus, feminonucleus.
A small euphorbiaceous tree, Acalypha rubra, formerly of St. Helena, now extinct. It was a handsome tree, named from its pendent spikes of reddish male, flowers.
In botany, a male sexual cell.
Fear of or repugnance to the male sex.
A male cook.
A male singer.
Among the pagan Tagalogs, a sorceress or witch; also (in Spanish use), a male sorcerer or priest.
The male European robin, Erythacus rubecula. The name is most familiar in a nursery rime.
A widely distributed bird (Phasianus colchicus) native to the Old World, the male of which has a long pointed tail, brightly colored plumage, and a white ring around the neck.
An efficient, faithful male aide or employee.
A North American blackbird (Euphagus carolinus), the male of which has blue-black feathers in the spring that turn rust-colored in the fall.
A North American blackbird (Agelaius phoeniceus), the male of which has scarlet patches on the wings. Also called redwing.
In psychoanalysis, a subconscious sexual desire in a child, especially a male child, for the parent of the opposite sex, usually accompanied by hostility to the parent of the same sex.
A tanager (Piranga ludoviciana) of western North America, the male of which is yellow with a red head and a black back.
Slang   A person, especially a male prostitute, who engages in or appears likely to engage in such acts.
An adult male voice with a range above that of tenor.
A male prostitute hired by telephone.
A North American warbler (Dendroica striata), the male of which has a black cap.
a woman television reporter who coordinates a broadcast to which several correspondents contribute. Male correlate of anchorwoman.
The supreme male divinity of the Phoenician and Canaanitish nations.
A male voice, the compass of which partakes of the common bass and the tenor, but which does not descend as low as the one, nor rise as high as the other.

A specialized group of four tentacles on the right side of some male cephalopods, as the nautilus, three of them having their sheaths united and the fourth standing alone. The structure is opposite to the spadix; hence the name.
In biology, a male genoblast.
The common male fern, Aspidium Filix-mas, from the basket-like form of its growth.
A young male calf: often applied in contempt to persons.
A male calf.
An inflorescence consisting of a cuplike cluster of modified leaves enclosing a female flower and several male flowers, as in the poinsettia.
A male child nourished or reared like an own son, though not such by birth.
The male widgeon, Mareca penelope; the yellowpoll.
A groom; a footman; a male attendant; a follower.

In logic, a mnemonic name of a syllogism of the first figure, all whose parts are universal affirmative propositions: as, All men are mortal; all the patriarchs (Enoch, Elijah, etc.) are men; hence, all patriarchs are mortal.

In logic, the mnemonic name of a kind of syllogism the premises of which are those of a syllogism in barbara (which see), while the conclusion is only a particular instead of a universal affirmative: as, All men are mortal; all kings are men; hence, some kings are mortal.
A necessary inference having a single premise and a disjunctive conclusion: as, Enoch and Elijah did not die; hence, either Enoch and Elijah were not men, or some men do not die.
